results.justification: The document explicitly states the research aims to develop a cross-cultural confusion detection model and evaluate it in a classroom setting. The overall approach is clearly outlined.
Sections 3.1 through 3.7 provide a detailed, step-by-step description of the study design, including data curation, CNN training, evaluation metrics, and RAG implementation.
The document mentions using two open-sourced datasets: DAiSEE [18] and DevEmo [33].
While the authors collected their own dataset (Eastern Asian), it is not stated whether this dataset is publicly available. There is no mention of making it open.
Section 3.1 provides detailed information about the datasets, including the number of subjects, videos, frames, and labels. It also describes the data preprocessing steps.
Data collection methods are fully described for each dataset, including instructions given to participants (for the authors' dataset) and details about the existing datasets.
The document does not mention whether the analysis code is shared in an open repository.
Since the code is not mentioned as being shared, there is no justification needed.
The document mentions using MTCNN for facial recognition, but does not state whether the code used for data preparation is shared.
Statistical tests (Kolmogorov-Smirnov test), models (CNN), and assumptions are described, though not exhaustively.
Accuracy, and other metrics are reported for the CNN models. Statistical significance (p-values) are mentioned in relation to the KS test.
The document includes qualitative interpretation of the SHAP values and the word cloud analysis, providing context and insights.
While SHAP analysis is used, the detailed coding and analysis process isn't fully shared. The description focuses on the results rather than the coding scheme.
Results are presented clearly using tables, figures, and descriptive text. The findings are well-organized and easy to follow.
Section 5.2 explicitly discusses limitations, including the lack of representation of all ethnicities, potential annotation bias, and camera angle issues.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration.
